title: Personal Space & Togetherness
description: Explore how you balance individual needs with couple time.

questions.text: When it comes to alone time, I...
choices: Need regular time to recharge by myself
Enjoy it occasionally but prefer being together
Can take it or leave it depending on the day
Sometimes forget I need it until I'm depleted

therapeutic.rationale: Alone time needs reflect introversion/extroversion and self-care awareness. Regular needers require solitude to function; togetherness-preferrers energize through connection; flexible types adapt; depleted-discoverers need better self-awareness. Understanding this prevents resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different alone time needs can cause friction. The recharge-needer may seem distant; the togetherness-preferer may seem needy. Negotiate what works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched alone time needs create natural rhythm of together and apart.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much alone time do you need? Does your partner understand and respect this?

choices: Have dedicated quality time just for us
Are comfortable being alone together
Balance couple time with individual pursuits
Stay connected even when doing our own things

therapeutic.rationale: Togetherness preferences reveal connection needs. Dedicated-time lovers need focused attention; alone-together types need presence without pressure; balancers need rhythm; connected-apart types need ongoing thread. All are valid ways of being together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different togetherness preferences require negotiation. The dedicated-time lover may feel the balancer is distant. Find what works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched togetherness preferences create natural harmony in how you spend time.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What kind of togetherness feels best to you? Is that what you're experiencing?

choices: Respect it and give you room
Sometimes take it personally at first
Am happy to have my own time too
Check in to make sure we're okay

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to partner's space needs reveal attachment security. Respecters have secure acceptance; personal-takers may have anxious attachment; happy-for-own-time shows secure independence; checkers may need reassurance. Understanding your response helps you improve it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses to space needs are normal. The personal-taker may need reassurance that space isn't rejection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched responses create smooth navigation of space needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when your partner needs space? Is that response serving your relationship?

choices: Intentional quality time together
Comfortable companionship without agenda
Respect for each other's individual needs
Balance between together and apart

therapeutic.rationale: Togetherness desires reveal what's missing. Intentional-time wishers want more focus; companionship-wishers want more ease; respect-wishers want more autonomy; balance-wishers want better rhythm. Naming what you want helps you create it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different togetherness desires point to different needs. Both are valid and can often both be addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared desires create clear direction for improving your together/apart balance.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you like more of in terms of together and apart time?

choices: Maintain their individual identities
Prioritize their relationship
Find a balance that works for both
Support each other's need for space and closeness

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about togetherness shape expectations. Identity-maintainers protect individuality; relationship-prioritizers protect connection; balancers seek both; flexible-supporters adapt to needs. All perspectives have value.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs about togetherness require conversation. Find the balance that honors both perspectives.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy creates aligned expectations about space and togetherness.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you believe about balancing individuality and togetherness in relationships?
